posts.com: So how does Pokerus work in this? I know it can only effect eggs and only ones that you manually put in the daycare, but beyond that I am not sure what to do and if I can fuck it up somehow if I don't watch out what I am doing and lock out a large amount of my team from getting it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52961388
the recipient has to match one of the types of the infected eggs being hatched

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52961388
You can't mess it up in any way. Pokerus spreads between eggs in the daycare that share a typing. Newly infected eggs cannot immediately spread it until they've hatched. "Contagious" and "Resistant" are misnomers: Contagious just means it has pokerus with less than 50 EVs accumulated while Resistant means you passed that point and will see diminishing returns on EV gain. Both spread it the same.

I would note that there is a pretty clear difference between Charizard starting as a bipedal lizard and saying a bipedal lizard, and Litten starting as a quadruped and turning into a biped.
That aside, it's more about what >>52953049 said, where the issues people have are more about being too humanoid or having a blatant job, and they're simply using bipedal incorrectly when trying to describe it.

Even looking at your image though, you can tell at a glance that there's a lot more red at the top of the chart than the bottom. Personally though, I'd say that starters should strive for variety regardless. Starters are the pokemon that every player is going to get, so it's best to try to use a broad range of designs for a similarly broad range of appeal.

>>52956371
Rough timeline of mythical distros alongside their movies in every gen since the backwards compatibility cutoff, since Mew and Celebi were given space in other movies during their remakes to obviously promote them again.

2003- Jirachi
2004- Deoxys
2005- gap year (Lucario movie; Mew distro for Kanto remakes + Emerald)
2006- Manaphy
2007- Darkrai
2008- Shaymin
2009- Arceus
2010- (Zoroark movie with Celebi distro for Johto remakes), Victini
2011- gap year (Victini movie)
2012- Keldeo, Meloetta, Genesect (Keldeo movie)
2013- gap year (Genesect movie, promotion of Megas)
2014- Diancie
2015- Hoopa
2016- Volcanion, Magearna
2017- Marshadow
2018- Zeraora, Melmetal
2019- gap year (Mewtwo remake movie)
2020- Zarude
2021- no movie or mythical
2022- no movie or mythical

So it’s not 100% perfect “mythical per year” but there are always movies aimed at promoting some sort of “new” pokemon, be it a mythical distro or something from the upcoming Gen. Every movie except for M03 and the Mewtwo strikes back remake has fit the “promotion” aspect. Covid definitely cut into the movies as a business model, but they had already been in a decline since Hoopa’s essentially bombed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I always felt that the existence of a "champion" in Red/Blue was supposed to be some kind of plot twist
While there are talks about the E4 late in the game there is never a single mention about a fight after that, as far as the story goes there is not an already existing champion. In fact Lance's unique room layout and defeat speech works as some kind of fake out ("Congratulations, you are now the pokemon league champion... Or you would have been (...)")
Blue's situation then raises more questions. Did Kanto really not have a champion before Blue? Lance's dialogue implies so, but then wouldn't Lance be the de facto champion. The whole thing makes it seem like the extra battle is out of the ordinary and under normal circumstances beating the E4 should be enough. Maybe there was a champion once but he got old and decided to fuck off. Speaking of Lance, how exactly did he become the champion in Gen 2? Did he just inherit the title as the highest ranked member of the E4 or did he decide to leave the E4 and challenge them like the player seeing the title was up for grabs after Red and Blue escaped their duties?
In any case my main point is that in the original game the "battle against the champion" was supposed to be some sort of surprise and the developers expected you to believe that you were done once finishing the E4. Naturally once the series exploded in popularity and peak poke mania was a thing there was no way to keep the surprise intact, much less after the release of following generations, where there are clear hints of a champion battle and the idea of an established champion was in place. Just thought it was curious to point out this yet another gen 1 oddity that often gets ignored.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52960621
Play LGPE, until the events of gen 1, Kanto's league was like Alola's island challenge, you clear the objectives (gyms or trials) and then have the chance to beat the four greatest trainers in the famous mountain range of the region (Elite 4 in the Indigo Plateau or the Kahunas in Mount Lanakila) and then you are the champion (Pokemon League Champion in Kanto and Isladn Challenge Champion in Alola), but only until someone else does the same as you.
LGPE version of Red and Green are like Kahili in SM/USUM, they beat the four strongest so they are Champions, but they don't defend the title in any way. This only changed in Kanto/Alola right at the end when Green/you become the champion and fight the first challenger (Red/Hau).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: At the time, it makes sense as a subversion of RPG standards. There was a "big bad" (E4) hyped up across the game, and they exist as a final boss rush, emulating the "phases" of a final boss in any other jrpg. Plus, you just kicked your rival's ass, and every other time he shows up he stays gone for a while. So it makes sense that you'd already beaten him. Plus, other jRPGs at the time that try this subversion gives you a breather before throwing the true final boss at you (such as The Moon in Final Fantasy IV). So it would make sense if this was planned to be a twist boss.

>Would Cynthia hang out with Lance?
They go on dragon-related adventures together, Cynthia not quite being a dedicated dragon master but being accepted as one by the elders from her mastery of the likes of Garchomp and Kommo-o. They explore rugged wilderness, train by battling dangerous monsters, and occasionally busting up bad guys and saving the world/universe.

>Would Cynthia hang out with Steven
They go exploring ancient ruins in the middle of the desert or the jungle or something, like Laura Croft teaming up with Indiana Jones, except Steven keeps getting distracted by random cool rocks he finds lying around. Cynthia finds his nerding-out over geology amusing and he finds her nerding-out over anthropology inbteresting.

>Or does she prefer girls?
Diantha is too busy with glamour and Cynthia finds her boring. Iris is a minor and Cynthia isn't legally allowed to be within 100 feet of her. Geeta is a scrub and Cynthia has to resist the urge to dethrone her.

posts.com: Noob here, what does Hatterene "moving" to OU mean? Was it banned in UU? But doesn't it have reasonable counters in UU?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52945643
It just means that it got enough usage in OU to become OU. Smogon is a usage based tiering system so the more a Pokemon is used, the higher tier it is. Conversely, the less it's used, the lower tiered it is. Once every 3 months (or month early on), a Pokemon's usage stats are pulled and looked at, and depending on if it hits a certain usage threshold, it can either remain in a tier or drop to a lower one

Sometimes, Pokemon in lower tiers get enough usage in higher tiers to "rise", like Hatterene

You don't back up stackers, very few pokemon can, specifically ninetales/mamo can easily. Most stackers are just bad, they can't recognize when they can stack without griefing and throwing the lane. But that is a moot point, because no Internet poll will ever be a verifiable accurate gauge of the fandom's preferences in a series like this. Pokemon is a massive franchise, the number of votes the Google Worldwide Poll got is still minuscule compared to the number of people that buy the games. At the end of the day, any Internet poll is hard to take as a surefire benchmark when you consider populational and time factors. Just look at how Mimikyu completely pwned a wide range of monsters that we know for fact are more popular than it. Variations of that sort are expected and any analysis of the data is worthless without other comparison points.
Ultimately, Swadloon IS a meme and it was the mascot for years of one of the jap pokemon communities due to resembling a "neet loser". That is my point, we know who are the memes and who are not, and the poll, after you ignore the memes, blatantly shows that the popular ones are people we already knew are popular, and you have no reason to assume Inteleon, Corviknight and Alcremie are not popular Galar monsters and that this poll is a sham when we already had all of them ranking well in merch sales and in previous polls done before that one even in magazines. Again, look at all of the gens there, and when you ignore the memes they're really just populated by things we already know are popular in Japan. Inteleon obviously is unpopular/disliked outside of Japan, but we're talking about Japan.

>reminder that serperior is a plant before it is a snake, that it photosynthesizes for nutrition instead of eating...
First of all, we've literally seen wild Serperior eat things before (see pic related). Not to mention the fact that Serperior has a mouth and fangs (which wouldn't make sense on an animal that isn't a consumer).
Second of all, plants cannot produce everything they need through photosynthesis alone. Photosynthesis merely produces sugars which provide energy. The actual nutrients that a plant needs such as iron and calcium must be taken from the environment. Most plants do this using roots, while some plants also use others means... such as eating live prey.
>that every dex entry in its evolution line-up states this
Serperior's dex entries never state that it solely relies on photosynthesis. It would be pretty strange if it did, considering that it's been depicted eating stuff as I mentioned earlier.

>>52963207
>what's the point of this shitmon?
In many, many (J)RPGs, monster spawns are tied to your PC's EXP or point in the plot (if linear). At the start of your journey, small, weak monsters show up. As you progress, stronger and new or evolved forms of old monsters show up. In this franchise, the Pokemon are those monsters, with the only difference being they can be caught and trained. Therefore, most "shitmon" are basically just this franchise's early plot, low EXP (J)RPG monsters.

If you go for the gen 7 games, I'd suggest Sun & Moon over Ultra Sun & Ultra Moon. I may be biased though, but the original Sun & Moon are probably one of, if not my favourite games in the franchise, and they're what rekindled my love for Pokémon after I started drifting away from the series. So I'd highly recommend the original Sun & Moon.

Greatly depends on your taste, anon.
Gen 6
>XY is okay, Kalos is a pretty region
>ORAS Makes the best use of Gen 6 feature that is PSS
>ORAS has a good deal of interesting features and side quests: soaring, secret bases etc. Lots of lore here and there as well. It's imo the pinnacle of 3D Pokemon and Hoenn was one of the very good candidates with the 3D treatment

Gen 7
>In favor of 'story' Gen 7 tends to be drawn out in certain places where you simple just have to mash A to get through it. These are one of the first Pokemon games that really focus on human relationships with other humans more than humans relationships with Pokemon.
>Online features are worse than Gen 6, with festival plaza being confusing, random and requiring you to focus specifically on it instead of being able to focus on the main game simultaneously like with Gen 6
>Seems to have higher difficulty than Gen 6 but its mostly because most of the Pokemon there are so slow that you can't do the usual of over leveling and one-shotting like with other games
>Removes the charm of chibi overworld models in favor of going for full scale designs. Whether you like that or not is something you should see for yourself

posts.com:
https://www.siliconera.com/funny-stories-of-pokemon-english-name-localizations/
>Seth McMahill, Assistant Manager of Product Marketing at Nintendo, has been working exclusively on Pokémon games throughout his career at the company.
>When we spoke with McMahill recently, we asked if he had any interesting or amusing stories to tell from his days localizing the older games. McMahill recalled a couple of instances for us.
>“When you’re naming them, you’re together in a room with a counterpart from NCL (Nintendo Co. Ltd.),” McMahill shared. “We would basically have a thesaurus, a whiteboard on the wall, and would lock ourselves in for days on end, and the days would turn into months.”
>He continued: “The craziest one is… my wife was about to have a baby. So I’m at home, going through baby name books. I’m at work, going through baby name books, along with thesauruses and dictionaries. And after a while, stuff starts to sound weird. So, we had Piplup (Japanese name: Pochama), and the description from Japan was: ‘the sound of a small pebble in the water’. That was what we had to come up with.”
>McMahill recalls: “What we came up with was Piploop, which sounded like ‘poop’.”
>“And we didn’t even think of that,” he says. “No one thought of it. And we were talking to another group, saying we’d finally figured it out, and they went: ‘Poop?’ They said it sounded like poop. And I said, ‘It does not sound like poop! You don’t know what you’re talking about; I’ve been doing this for years!'”
>“And then, finally, after a good night’s rest, I thought: ‘That does sound like poop…’ So, we ended up with Piplup, which was the final name.”

>>52939177
I posted in this thread last week about buying the set of Magical Pokemon Journey volumes in Japanese. They came in today.

One really bizarre thing that people who've seen the raws may or may not know is that the printed volumes literally cut off the text that goes past the designated page borders. Like one panel just a few pages into the first volume has one kanji just cut in half by the top of the page, and the entire last line of dialogue in another panel of the same chapter is cut off along the left side. It's the sloppiest shit I've ever seen in a Japanese manga edition, to the point that I wondered if I got some weird bootlegs and that's the reason they were so cheap. But nope, looking up the raws shows the same problem exists in the scans from, what, a decade or two ago, so this is all Flower Comic's fault I guess.

(check out the panel on the bottom left of the left page-- you can juuuust see a portion of the last line of dialogue in the speech bubble that's cut off, and in my physical copy it's even more visible than in this old scan because you can make out just a bit more of it)

The volumes are also weirdly... wide or something compared to a standard manga volume and the pages are really white/thick, like they're made of a different kind of paper than usual.

That's my shitty review so far I guess. I haven't even read it yet but it just amazed me to see an official release in the original language be so sloppy in that kind of way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52953127
Also it's def possible that was deliberate for a joke, like she's yelling so much the text gets cut off and I'm just overreacting because it doesn't come off well, but since I have seen a few manga that cut off more of the art/text than the original magazine displayed it's a weird way to start the book. Especially when the format they printed it in is already weird.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52953162
Yeah okay last thing I'll say about this:

It's def at least partially a weird page border/printing deal because flipping through the whole book I see some instances of eyes etc. being cut off by the edges of the pages in a way that seems unlikely for them to have been originally drawn that way, and also some images of Ciao magazine scans on google showing a bit more of the full image. Meaning that it seems the way it's reprinted for the volumes shaves off a bit of the art.

It's pretty minor and overall the books look fine and even have some color pages, which look really vibrant and have a fun retro Pokemon vibe. NO idea why I got fixated on this so hard but it instantly just struck me as weird.

>Ace
Froslass
>Team
Ice/Ghost, Fluttermane can be interchangeable with Mismagius

>Inside Gym theme
https://youtu.be/Ms_WPizqN9o with a few traditional japanese notes
>Battle theme
https://youtu.be/V2jRaufDfQQ

>Gym Aesthetic
An old abandonned traditional japanese manor on top of a snowy mountain. The manor itself is half-destroyed in some parts and the snow can come in.
The climb to the gym is hindered by a huge blizzard, with ice types roaming, and also ghost types at night.
It is difficult to find your way in the storm, but you will ocasionally see fom afar a beautiful woman dressed entirely in a white yukata with white hair and pale skin that doesn't seem entirely human, seemingly show you the way to the top.
Be careful however as she is quite mischevious and will sometimes bring you in obvious traps or misdirections that will make you lose your way in deep snow that make it difficult to walk.
Once you find the gym, she will be there more often but will completely lead you astray and make you lose yourself in rooms and encounter climbers or posessed spiritualists that will challenge you in battle. The trick to find the right way is not to trust her anymore at that point.
The gym leader is a beautiful woman not unlike the one that guided you through the snow, but with jet-black long hair going to her waist, and normal skin. The two share a strange ressemblance as if they were related.

The battle opens with Snow Warning Ninetales (Or it will hail/snow in the gym leader room by default) and ends with Snow Cloak Froslass. The ghosts have stuff like will-o-wisps (cold can "burn") and destiny bond.
Naturally all the special ice types will use Blizzard and not Ice Beam as their main ice STAB

Badge ideas:
A ghostly ice-blue flame
A white yukata sash
A white traditional japanese fan with purple complexions

The gym will mysteriously be absent during the day, and there will only be a vast empty area with some few wooden ruins standing in its place...

posts.com:
>ace
H. Zoroark
>battle theme
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q6FHO70J2u8
>gym aesthetic
A nice cottage whose interior walls are all wood, with lots of comfy sofas completely covered with big, puffy pillows all overs, nice soft rugs, beds with the softest bedding, basically a place where my Pokemon and backup trainers could lounge all day. It would be decorated with warm Christmas hanging from the ceiling or around the various balconies, with candles lit up to truly seal that comfy atmosphere. The leader's Pokemon are all quite high maintenance with their hair's health and overall appearance, that's why they spend most of the day sitting lazily like divas, so as to not mess up their looks.

The challenge would involve all of the candles being automatically put off and the challenger having to go all around the cottage trying to light them up before the time limit, but sometimes hallways or balconies will be blocked off by trainers who will either battle or give a quick quiz question before letting them through.

Only chose this character because of the hair, the gym leader would actually be a woman with long, white hair on a ponytail, wearing comfortable sleeping clothes (loose tank top and pants, with a transparent lace pajama coat on top), whom upon meeting is currently brushing her Zoroark. Upon seeing you she will pretend to be annoyed that you're interrupting her relax time and making her stand up (she's very lazy), but in reality she's really excited and was eagerly waiting for a challenger. By clapping her hands, she recalls all of her Pokemon into her room, where they'll promptly go back into their balls and the battle will begin.

The badge would be a white pillow that doubles as a cloud, with those string things that pillows have on the corners being lilac.

Oh I was just going for comfy vibes in general, a place to be really laid-back, hence the setting being kinda like picrel, everyone wearing comfy clothes/pajamas, the Pokemon just chilling around over the cushy pillows (since the mons have long hair I figured they'd just lay around, letting it all hang freely so as to not get tangled), the warm candles and lights, etc. (also maybe these kind of lights are called something else, but I associate these string like lights with Xmas ones, so maybe that caused the confusion? At first glance it appears to be a simple cave but the first opening area has a series of caverns crawling with researchers. The "challenge" is simple, you must pay close attention to which scientist are actually doing their job and which ones are complaining(Complaints range from the state of the gym and the temperature to how they just outright dislike being forced to be gym trainers). The ones complaining will give you not so subtle hints that point you in the direction of the cavern you should go down. As you progress deeper into the caves temperature will steadily drop, the walls turning to ice until you find the gym leader in a room ice surrounded by ice furniture and 2 sculptures.
You'll learn he's a living relic from the past that was defrosted. Due to his knowledge he would've been taken in but his battle prowls made it rather difficult. So instead a deal was struck, if he was supplied with food and left alone with his family(the 2 ice sculptures) he would in turn answer any questions the researchers had about the past and become a gym leader.

When you win, a small boat/car will take you to the league.

>>52961434
Given that we've gone back and forth between a form change gimmick and elemental gimmicks, I get the feeling we're due for another form change gimmick after Terastalization to continue the pattern. As such, I believe our next gimmick will be what I will dub "Aetherfusion".

Much like Dynamaxing and Gigantimaxing, there are two types of Aetherfusion: normal Aetherfusion and Daiaetherfusion. Both can be performed once the player receives their Aether Gauntlet or whatever stupid MacGuffin is needed to activate it. It can only be done once per battle to boost a single Pokemon
>When Aetherfusion is used, the Pokemon will absorb the life energy of another Pokemon on the player's team, rendering that other Pokemon unusable for the rest of the battle. They're not Fainted, but they can't be used
>The Pokemon that Aetherfusion is used on receives a variety of effects depending on the Pokemon whose life energy they absorbed. Examples include having their attack stat raised if the other mon is physically powerful like Hitmonlee or Machamp, or being healed if the other mon has high HP like Chansey or Audino
>Powerful Pokemon can bestow more powerful buffs on the Aetherfused Pokemon, however these also come with some drawbacks, such as +2 Attack and Sp.Atk at the cost of their defenses being lowered by one stage, being completely healed of all ailments but becoming confused, or being immune to all damage at the cost of fainting within 3 turns and not being able to switch out
>Most Legendary/Mythical Pokemon cannot be Aetherfused due to having too much life energy inside of them already (Read: competitive balance), though there are exceptions: Lugia can Aetherfuse with the Legendary Birds to boost its stats by one stage, Eternatus can Aetherfuse with Pokemon described as power sources such as Victini to transform Dynamax Cannon into Eternabeam, and Arceus can be Aetherfused with any mon to become that mon's primary type, regardless of what Plate is held
(Cont.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52963392
>Daiaetherfusion is only usable by certain Pokemon with certain Pokemon, usually those who are counterparts or share some lore between eachother
>When used, both Pokemon fuse into a new form. This form boasts a new design, improved base stats, a new ability, and combines the primary typings of both Pokemon. The held item, nature, EVs, IVs and moveset are dependant on the Pokemon you Daiaetherfuse
>Certain signature moves will become empowered upon Daiaetherfusion, transforming into new moves exclusive to these forms
>Much like Aetherfusion, most Legendary/Mythical Pokemon cannot Daiaetherfuse, though exceptions exist: Kyurem can be Daiaetherfused with Reshiram or Zekrom to fuse mid-match into their respective formes, and Dusk Mane/Dawn Wings Necrozma can be Aetherfused with Solgaleo or Lunala to become Ultra Necrozma

Examples of Daiaetherfusion forms would include:
>Pikachu and Eevee, who become a softer, fluffier Pikachu with Eevee's ears and chest tuft, with a puffy Pikachu-like tail. Normal/Electric Type with Speed Boost as its ability, great special attack and speed but low defenses
>Zangoose and Seviper, who become a larger Zangoose with sharper claws and a big, long snake for a tail that wraps around its body and neck. A Normal/Poison Type with high attack and speed, but middling defenses. Has the ability Corrosion
>Cofagrigus and Trevenant, who become a big wooden coffin with arms made from vines, two sets of wooden spider legs, and three piercing red eyes. Becomes a Ghost/Grass Type with the new ability "Glossy Finish", which reduces supereffective damage. Is very bulky and has decent offenses, but it very slow
>Charizard and Greninja, who become a Fire/Water Type samurai dragon. Gains the new ability Draconic Soul, which increases the power of Dragon Type moves by 50%, as well as turning Water Shuriken into a new signature move called Scalding Firework, a 90BP Water Type move that is also the Fire Type and damages all surrounding Pokemon

>>52944505
I've only got 3 units at 150 (Adler, H.Caitlyn and Ghetsis) and that was only because I couldn't clear the SS Hilbert extreme battle without doing so. 140 has so far been enough for everything in MM.
In terms of leeway, you can get a couple of teams that can just off-type whatever you need them to so they can be thought of as 'get out of jail free' cards. I also have a toxistall team with SS Leaf, The Iris Formerly Known as Champion, and a tank that heals on sync (I now have H.Caitlyn but Sawyer worked totally fine before her).
The most important thing is having busted support units since they don't care about typing. After that you want to look into having powerful strikers in different types.
Lastly, you should be smart about what handicaps you put on. You can make things way harder on yourself if you do suboptimal choices.

>KEEP WITH MINIMAL CHANGES OUTSIDE COSMETICS
Pikachu, Puff, Mewtwo, Lucario

Trainer, changed so that all Pokemon now have a Down Special and you swap them with a different button command. Trainer now has a "Cheer" mechanic similar to Tera Raids, and the Pokemon go back to having something like fatigue but in reverse (they gain or lose momentum based on trainer's decisions). >GONE

>ADD
The only guarantee I think they should and will add is Cinderace with a soccer ball gimmick (it's constantly dribbling and can kick/rebound the ball to pull off cool combos, but when it kicks the ball it must go retrieve it). He'll always go for the "oh, this reminds me of this cool thing I can remember" choice instead of the "this has neat potential and would please the fans" choice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52939276
Depends on the selection of mons you're including. It could result in cases where fast and frail mons miss out on some key one-shots, and thus get knocked out more easily in return. It also makes bulky pokemon with reliable recovery more valuable, since they'll be taking less damage and healing it off more easily.

For an in-game playthrough though, the differences are more likely to be fairly minimal, so long as you aren't intentionally designing enemy teams around abusing the extra bulk.

I would personally add them as companions/followers that don't take up a party slot. That way you can have their personality and appearance but not need to tinker with balance or figuring out how to make them something the player will want to use. Other anons made valid points that adapting the LGPE partner system isn't a terrible approach either, but I would recommend they are part of a pool you can select from / earn throughout the game.

I would personally implement them as a Pokemon that provides a noticeable buff to your team, similar to badge buffs. That way people who want to use their favorites have even more reason to do so, and others can use specific mons to craft a team that leverages that advantage. A lot of potential depth there with minimal investment, and you don't need to give up letting them be used in battle.

>>52939209
The truth isn't determined democratically. Doesn't matter how many hate hearing this.

The process of running back and forth to the Pokemon Center to heal is dull. It's not gameplay, it's tedium best removed from the experience, or sped up.

You're trading seconds of IRL life for a heal ingame. Would anything fundamentally vital to the core gameplay loop of finding and catching Pokemon and battling trainers be lost if this process was 6x faster? Would it do anything good for that loop if the process took 6x longer?

Would anything really change if there was a Key Item that healed you on the spot after being forced to wait for the time it would take for your player character to run back to the Pokemon Center?
Like a facebook game for wine aunts?
Could be argued that the choice to use a Pokemon center instead of a limited supply of healing items is an interesting choice, but that would be FUCKING WRONG, because enough grinding gives you infinite money.

Ever play Dark Souls?

The only Dark Souls game I've played so far respawns enemies if you run back to heal.
The player is punished for running back to heal. This turns running back to heal into a choice with trade offs.
Is it worth running back to heal, and re-doing this route again? Would you do better this time, know what to watch out for, improve as a player? It also ensures any moment where you take damage puts you closer to death and the need to retry. This adds tension to the combat. Makes you avoid damage. Speeds up the process of dying to restore your health and retry the challenge again, adds tension to that by making you lose something when you die.

No meaningful interesting choices are made when gameplay boils down to "mash A for a bit" or "backtrack to the pokemon center and backtrack back to where I was" and nothing is lost by speeding this process up.

Do you know what's gained when this process is sped up?

Time.

>>52955080
I think you would enjoy Peridot, assuming you're not the dev here.

Gyms are dungeons you can't leave unless you black out or beat the gym leader. You better come prepared with healing items and ethers or else you will have some trouble getting through. Items are more expensive and trainers give less money so you won't be carrying more than 10 or so hyper potions and revives even by the end game. You also can't heal in battle with the gym leader, the game is defaulted to set (but you can change to switch in the options) and the game heavily limits grinding because Pokémon will stop obeying if you train past 5 or so levels above the gym leader.

It's challenging but not unfair and every design choice is deliberate. The actual map design is also very good, free and interconnected.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52955080
In a single player game, there is no relevant resource other than the player's time. Every in-game resource is simply a representation of that time.
Therefore, the core decision that can be made in every single player game is the following: whether to spend time grinding for more resources, or to spend time figuring out a way to progress with less resources.
Every good game disincentivizes the former and incentivizes the later.
Consider Dark Souls. Enemies respawn every time you run back to heal, which allows you to infinitely grind for levels. And yet few players opt for this route. Most players simply fight the boss of each level over and over again until they figure out the fight and can win with the levels and weapons they currently have. Why? Because grinding for souls is boring, time consuming, and mind numbing. This is the core decision of Dark Souls: spend time grinding levels, or spend time learning boss fights.
Ever play Factorio? Consider handcrafting in Factorio. You click on the item you want and then watch progress bars complete, and then you get the item. There is no crafting system in the world that is more boring than handcrafting in Factorio. That is because the game is trying to push players towards automating crafting of items. This is the core decision of Factorio: spend time handcrafting, or spend time figuring out how to automatically craft items.
Now consider where this decision lies in Pokemon games. Backtracking to the Pokemon Center and using healing items are BOTH examples of the former, spending time to grind resources. Then what should Pokemon games be incentivizing players to do? Team building and battling in ways the minimize HP lost, minimize status conditions inflicted on your pokemon, minimize PP spent. When the time cost of healing your pokemon back up is sped up, it is no longer worthwhile to spend time figuring out how to minimize your loses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52955783
The only umbrage I take with taking souls as an example is that any fight is winnable with any set of tools, provided you grind enough to know windows of opportunity. If a game does not have explicit or even implicit windows on opportunity, this design style fails. Pokemon may have a few cheese strats you can lean on, but unless you are specifically seeking them you MUST have a certain amount of resources (levels and moves) to be able to clear specific battles. You can be the entirety of Dark Souls with your fists alone - your knowledge of boss fight behaviors is your resource here. Knowledge resources can turn the tide in Pokemon, but they will not beat the entire game for you (again, outside of very specific cheese strategies).
The core argument is sound though. Speed up is a crutch used by hacker and player alike - grinding rather than facing challenges, resetting rather than learning to make due. It is on both the hack designer and the player to meet in the middle on gameplay mechanics. As it currently stands, you should be using potions in the field if backtracking would take too long / not be fun. It's the reason things like Ether/Elixir even exist. Speed up does trivialize the time investment, invalidating some of these core gameplay designs.

>>52955783
>>52955883
The best RPGs aren't RPGs.
They are challenges of the mind that don't allow grinding to break them. Puzzles, in a sense. Or execution tests. And what kind of a puzzle allows itself to be broken by hours of trying to put the square peg in the round hole? What kind of test says "You've failed enough times, I give up, you pass by default"?

Level caps, limited resources, even limited time. There are ways to limit the player's capacity to grind infinitely.

You can limit resources and power and adjust that limit over time to ensure players don't accidentally or intentionally overlevel your intended challenges, or limit resources and power by limiting the time you have to exchange for these before the game says "Time's up!".

When the game has a time limit every decision becomes a choice with intentionality behind it, and thought put into it.

But for thought to go into playing a game, more thought has to go into designing it.
>>52955883
The designer places Pokemon that can be used to defeat the bosses and decides when they learn moves that can be useful against the bosses.
Factorio is about optimizing grind away with automation.

>How exactly do you get them into the games?
I use a software called PKhex and utilize my hack switch running custom firmware. Atmosphere for switch. I dump my game file into PKHex and edit it from there and then overwrite my current game file with the edited one.

Yeah I can help with that. I just need a pokemon you've bred or caught yourself to obtain the information.
>Can we already get the pokemon coming with Home or are they not in the game files yet?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Honestly Crystal specifically does have some issues.
Crystal removes mons like Mareep and GIrafarig and moved Magmar to Kanto. This makes teambuilding more annoying. I find that mid-Johto the available pokemon lack in fire power. I think the distribution is too dependent on the Odd Egg too, having to reset and hatch the egg constantly to get a decent Fire or Electric type sucks. But you do still have the Elemental punches available, so if you ever get tired you can just load them up on a Kadabra or Typhlosion and just fuck the game up.
Otherwise I think Johto games are fine. Grinding isn't hard, you can use the good and super rods to fish up pokemon that give decent exp, surfing gives good exp too. Trainers in the Johto portion of the game aren't very high leveled anyway so you don't need to grind much. Whitney and Morty are the hardest bosses in Johto and they can be dealt with. HGSS's rematch system is also pretty good for exp, it sucks that it's limited based on what day it is but you can call trainers for rematches quickly.

>>52960822
It was a strange time. Since people born in 2004 can all post on this website now, X and Y would have been maybe their second or third Pokemon games, maybe even their first. Coming off of B2W2 as a person who was old enough at the time to see the critique that there was no Battle Frontier (yes, this was a valid critique at the time since the previous 2 gens established that there would be at the end of the generation at the very least- plus there was no Stadium game for the first time for gen 5), we didn't really know what to expect but were optimistic that the series was going to be amazing on the 3DS with the more powerful hardware. Unfortunately, we were let down enough so that it really did start the trend of a new generation releasing and people saying it was the worst generation ever. I still view it as the worst generation ever, but I cannot deny the fact that it did bring with it some very important staples for the series in terms of multiplayer connectivity.
When the trailer was released? It was standard fare really, just showing off some of the new Pokemon as well as some of the locations in the game. They leaned a bit heavily into this as they wanted to showcase how the games looked. I was rightfully hyped because Colosseum/GoD showed me how good a 3D Pokemon game could be, plus the 3DS had hardware comparable/on-par with the GameCube. I think I was probably the most hyped for Sword and Shield's release for the nu-era, and of all time I was most hyped for HGSS, enough so that I actually asked my parents if they could get me a copy early from Japan despite me having no real way of reading Japanese.

Here’s an example of it in its current state. It doesn’t have c.ai intelligence. It cannot do robust, or very long term discussion. And the interface and UI right now are lacking. But it blows any other existing 6B models out of the water due to data quality. And anons are already working hard on getting new interfaces and front-ends running (TavernAI and KoboldAI people have already reached out).

We don’t know how big c.ai is, because the devs are ex-google fucks who won’t share an ounce of information about their black-box shit. We assume their model is about 135-175b (”b” is ‟billions of parameters” that the ai was fed before it was trained). This is just 6b. It’s obviously not as smart. But it’s already made leaps and bounds from how it once was. Try the smaller models on the collab page, to compare. They weren’t even coherent before, and now you can have real cybersex. And the Pygmalion team want to make a 13b model next. And then eventually a 20b model, which will be so big they’ll need to find their own server farm. Right now everyone’s focused on making this easier to use, though.

A part of making the AI requires taking a lot of training data in. They've made a form where anons can send in their c.ai rp logs as to help (fully anonimized). By their words, progress has been much faster than expected.

These people are the only ones giving our waifus a future. They’re open-source, reachable, and, unlike c.ai, their bots are getting better with time, instead of degrading. So, the least you can do is download your c.ai logs, and submit them so they can train those bigger models. It’s the best way to contribute if you’re not tech-savvy.

>horsefuckers made voice AIs
Nah, well, not directly.
Paraphrasing and misremembering bits abound!:
15.ai was intended to be for general use, just some rando guy looking to set his wallet on fire to impress his college by trying to generate entire voice AIs from as little data as possible, such as, well, 15 seconds of recordings of a given character.

After a while, Bronies caught wind that he was looking for more datasets, so they dumped a metric fuckton, an absolute autistic assload of well-curated and labeled voice clips from various sources, far better done than any other uploads, so he implemented the voices pretty quick and they turned out great, but it meant that now the site's best and most numerous bots are all MLP stuff.
This caught the attention of anti-bronies which all got mad that their submissions weren't getting that kind of priority, and the 15.ai dev fought back with what was basically "their uploads were great, it'd be stupid NOT to use them" and that just made more people mad, so he switched his profile pic to Twilight and just rolled with it.

posts.sub: ITT: You wake up in the Pokemon World
posts.com:
You wake up in the Pokemon World. Beside you is an egg of your favourite pokemon. Your Rotom phone pings and shows that you're on the outskirts of your favourite pokemon town/city. You have no money, but you can pick up a temp job in town based on your current skills/interests.

1) Who's in the egg? (If you don't have a favourite pick the pokemon that would be best to traverse with you on this journey, no legendaries or mythicals)
2) What town/city are you near?
3) What's your plan?
4) What are your goals? (In this world, you can become a trainer at any time, similar to SV)

Bonus: Pick a whole team. You may want to think about who would be your surf, fly, strength pokemon if you plan to be a travelling trainer taking on the gyms.

posts.com:
One of the most interesting developments is the rise of the eeveelutions into the mainstream. A big part of that rise was the Vaporeon copypasta and the powers of memes but it's something that's really surfacing. Not only reflected in smash or pass polls but also in general popularity among even the general image boards. There's also the fact of people being open about that attraction in big social media sites and in open spaces with lots of people. I've always said that the way Pokémon is constructed leaves very little in terms of "moral" superiority because of the series lack of distinction between Pokémon.

What prompted this post is the fact that Vaporeon overtook Gardevoir as the most upvoted Pokémon post in r/rule34 with 9k upvotes. I've mentioned that this is a place where there's over a million subscribers and where people constantly upvote girls cosplaying so it's a very vanilla sub. I've pointed out how results in other general imageboards are pretty close when it comes to Pokémon, even Gelbooru shows Pokémon clumping together in what is a imageboard geared towards anime fans. For example Lopunny being the most popular image of a Pokémon there. It shouldn't be a surprise because smash or pass reveals small differences between Pokémon in the upper echelons but what is surprising, at least to me, is the rise of the eeveelutions even outside of the pokephile sphere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Most of them.
Legends Arceus was right to cut 80% of them.

Okay, but I'll give an actual answer for each generation
>I: Rage
Holy fuck what were they thinking with that move in Gen 1. I'd rather be caught using fucking Razor Wind over Rage.

>II: Fury Cutter
Still shit in modern gens, but it was beyond shit when it first came out. A completely pathetic move.

>III:Flatter
literally just Confuse Ray, but objectively worse. Confusion has never scaled off of special attack, and now with he confusion nerf in Gen 6+, it's even more worthless than it was before.

>IV: Captivate
I have no idea why it's restricted to gender when something like Charm isn't and is obviously ti's equlivant. Has literally never been used because of it. Guess game freak agreed since they just removed it from the series

>V: Wonder Room/Glaciate
Wonder Room is just too niche, and Glaciate is just a slightly stronger Icy Wind that is exclusive to a Pokemon that never uses it

>VI: Magnetic Flux
I'd understand if it worked for the user AND Pokemon with plus/minus as an ability, but it works ONLY on Pokemon with those abilities. At least make it +2 if it's gonna be that niche. Pokemon that can't even get plus/minus as abilities can learn the move.

>VII: Prismatic Laser
Naming exclusive moves feels unfair, but it's a damn Hyper Beam clone.

>VIII: Branch Poke
It wans't enough that we just got a low level early game grass move last gen, but we needed to get ANOTHER one that does the SAME EXACT THING. Did Game Freak forget that Leafage existed?

>IX: Pouce
"Lunge At Home" Don't understand why, since Lunge wasn't even all that amazing to begin with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Synchronoise is certainly a move that exists.
I think I understand the idea of what the move should do or at least the intent behind the move: a same-type vs same-type matchup move that can inflict strong damage without the need of switching to a different Pokemon, and in Doubles, can potentially work like Surf, except you (probably) won't hurt your ally Pokemon.
Except: It was weak as fuck on introduction, and even after its power buff in Gen 6, it still will always hit certain types for NVE damage, you know, like the move's own type.
And it doesn't help that mainly Psychic Pokemon get this move either.

I think this move would make more sense if it simply IGNORED type matchups to inflict strong neutral damage to Pokemon of the same type.
I guess one of the most comedic interactions of this move is that Eevee can learn it, which means Umbreon can, and Umbreon literally can't use it because Dark's immunity to Psychic. And that despite the name of the move (in both English and Japanese), it isn't considered a Sound-Based move, even though multiple Pokemon related to sound like Whismur, Chatot, or Chimecho can learn it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Rock has some really awful offensive moves. Bad enough that even Rampardos can't save them.

Both of Rampardos's strongest moves (Head Smash and Stone Edge) are sitting at only 80% accuracy. Having a 1/5 chance of your "super-powerful pokemon" just absolutely eating shit on the one turn it might be allowed to live is absolutely fatal for something as poorly-typed and defensively frail as Rampardos is.

You'd think that the high base power of those moves (150 and 120 respectively) would be enough to save them. Or you'd think that Sheer Force would help boost them to be strong enough that a chance of one-shotting a pokemon could outweigh a 20% miss chance. But no, Sheer Force is only going to buff a Rock Slide to the point where it's still slightly weaker than Stone Edge. Sheer Force doesn't boost the others.

So, if you want to do reliable damage with your five-head dino, you need to rely on off-type moves. You've got access to heavy hitters like Superpower, Double Edge, Earthquake, and Outrage for some physical damage (no buffs from Sheer Force, though). If you want Sheer Force, you'll have to step down with some weaker moves like Brick Break, Crunch, Fire Punch, Iron Head, Thunder Punch, and Zen Headbutt.

Whatever, you've got a moveset now.

Except it's weak as shit! Your STAB moves are going to backfire 20% of the time and leave you doing 0 damage. Your non-STAB moves are losing 33% of their damage capability. Any worthwhile move with 100 BP or more doesn't benefit from Sheer Force, so you don't even have that to cope with. Your weakest BP moves will be the ones doing the most reliable damage!

You're better off picking a Pokemon with better moves and better offensive typing, that still has a serviceable attack stat.

252+ Atk Sheer Force Rampardos Fire Punch vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Celebi: 282-332 (82.6 - 97.3%) -- guaranteed 2HKO

252+ Atk Blaziken Flare Blitz vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Celebi: 408-480 (119.6 - 140.7%) -- guaranteed OHKO

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52960454
I think the most in Yellow was for the last few gym leaders and the Elite 4. Koga's whole team has Toxic when they wouldn't normally otherwise, along with stuff like one of his Venonat having Double-Edge. Blaine has Flamethrower and Reflect on his Arcanine instead of Roar and Ember, and a Ninetales with Confuse Ray and Flamethrower. Giovanni also has a pretty good upgrade since most of his mons have Earthquake now, along with the Nidos getting Thunder. Lance similarly gets to load up his dragons with coverage on top of giving Aerodactyl a couple flying moves, rather than just spamming Hyper beam.
Prior to that though, early gym leaders didn't have as many changes or customization. Or at least not for the better. Surge has Mega Kick and Mega Punch on his Raichu, but he also lost his two other team members. Sabrina similarly traded out Mr. Mime and Venomoth for a single Abra with Flash and nothing else.

Gen 2 seemed to at least lean more into the gimmick of having Gym leaders make more use out of the TM they give you, like how Falkner's team all has Mud Slap, or Bugsy and Morty have Fury Cutter and Shadow ball on their respective aces. The problem there is that the moves themselves for most Gym leaders aren't very good. Still, I think that's where they started to get a proper grasp of how they wanted to handle movesets for important NPCs.

>>52962927
>>52961117
I'm not convinced at all that it's an oversight. Gen 1 as the point of origin was simply a wild west of game design for the franchise, so there just wasn't yet a notion that a boss fight couldn't have Pokemon with "illegal moves". Note also that Lance's party mons kinda circumvent the "only the ace mon gets to use a signature move" thing by all of them learning Hyper Beam naturally around the levels Lance has them at. The actual unique move property is then freed up for Barrier to take up the spot, to bolster Dragonite's defense and potentially forcing a player to assault it on the special side rather than physical (and thus also force the player to figure out Dragons are weak to Ice despite resisting most other elemental special attacking types).

posts.com: I originally assumed that /vp/ hated the gen 7 Pokémon as much as the rest of the post-gen 5 games, but it seems like many people here seem to think it has the best Pokémon designs out of all the 3D games. Please share which gen 7 Pokémon you like and explain why you like them.

>>52962157

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I really like the vast majority of the dex, and if I don't love one of the mons I can at least appreciate its design, there's honestly only a handful in gen 7's dex that I actively dislike.
Just going by dex order:
>Rowlet
Cute owl
>Decidueye
Cool owl
>Litten/Torracat
Basic fire cats, I like the simplicity of it and how Litten looks annoyed constantly.
>Popplio
Cute seal
>Pikipek line
Solid tropical regional bird, these guys are always cool
>Oricorio
Neat birds that are fun to use and look at, they're a well done dancing mon that makes sense
>Rockruff
Cute and determined puppy, floppy ears, 10/10
>Lycanrocs
A kickass take on split evos leading to a werewolf theme. I love all three forms and they're still one of my top favorites, although I wish Dusk had more inspiration from Midnight to make it really seem like a mix of the two, they're a cool mon, especially in the anime, but could they have at least given them new animations?
>Wishiwashi
I think they were having fun with different forms this gen, the school of fish thing they had going on was fun and creative
>Salandit/Salazzle
Poison/Fire is incredibly fun to play with, sleek lizards are neat.
>Wimpod/Golisopod
Scared little bug that runs away constantly, turns into a fucking beast at fighting if you care for it enough and believe in it. They're fantastic and Guzma owning one really tells a lot about his character in a subtle way.
>Type: Null/Silvally
I love this dude, it's a shame they never became as popular as a bunch of other mons from this generation, and I don't know why, they're a chimera, it's hard to not be cool with that theme. Playing the game and seeing Gladion bring this dude out with no context actually made me go "what the fuck?" in a Pokemon game, which was a fun experience.

I like a lot more of the mons than this, these guys are just the ones that came to mind off the top of my head and I don't want to create a massive wall of text more than I already have.

I can actually say I was there for this. Storytime:

>2012 European VGC held in UK
>Final is between guy named Ben and Spaniard named Ruben
>Everyone hates the spics in the VGC because they're rude, arrogant, and a bunch of assholes
>Ben is cosplaying Gary
>During the final the whole audience starts chanting "GARY! GARY!"
>Organisers try to get them to shut up, doesn't work
>Ruben wins, they get him up on stage
>He starts talking about how his wins were easy
>nobodylikedthat.jpg
>Few days later the official VGC page is updated
>Ben is listed as the winner instead
>Story finally emerges
>Turns out Ruben and his mates got drunk, pooped all over the corridor of the hotel they were staying it, and threw the shit all over the place
>Nintendo hears about this and disqualifies him
>Ruben posts a letter calling himself the champion and one of the best players in the world and begs Nintendo not to ban him as "Pokemon is my life."
>Nintendo does not give a fuck and still bans him

What a glorious drama that was.
